sp.p: O, I can eaſily believe you, ſiſter. We do not want to run a gadding like you girls; and ſo we are not the firſt to keep appointments of this nature. You muſt force us from our ſtudy, if you would have us. Look you, I would lay any wager that the Danbys, at leaſt, are hard at work, while we are ſpeaking.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, to ſettle what fine tricks they can contrive to put upon us.—But pray, Frank, is it true that papa will let us paſs the evening here? Our room above is ſo very ſmall, we could not have found room to turn ourſelves well round.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Could my papa refuſe you any thing, when I concerned myſelf to aſk it? Softly, little girl, do not diſcompoſe the papapers—Let them lie.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Keep that advice, Sir, to yourſelf: I meant to lay them ſmooth.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p:
No, no,
you cannot miſs; I am charged with that commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Truly, my papa could not have given it to ſo orderly a gentleman; let me at leaſt aſſiſt you then; and afterwards I will put the chairs in order. Theſe great books I ſhall remove firſt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do not think of touching them! At moſt I can permit you only to take one by one, and pile them up upon my hand. (She does ſo, till they reach his chin.)

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: There is enough.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: One more only. So—I have now ſufficient for one turn. (He takes a ſtep or two, when all the books fall down.)

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! there, there they go! Thoſe handſome books that papa would never let us touch! I fancy he will be greatly pleaſed to ſee them all tumbled together thus!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I had loſt the center of Gravity, as my tutor ſays; and you know, he is Gravity itſelf. (He picks the books up, but they tumble down as faſt as he gathers them.) Deuce take it! They have been at Sadler's Wells, I think, and learned to tumble ſure!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You will never finiſh, if I do not aſſiſt you. So, d'ye ſee, I will ſpread my apron, and do you ſtoop down and pile them in it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That is well thought, indeed! (Frank goes upon his knees, takes up the books, and places them in order in his ſiſter's apron.)

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Softly, brother, they will rub one againſt another! So; I have got them all, and now I will carry them into the cloſet. (She goes out.)

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: (riſing out of breath.) Bleſs me! I ſhould never do to live in the country where men go upon all-fours like monkies. (He fans himſelf with his hat.)

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Could you ſee how neatly I have ranged them on the chimney, you would be charmed! So let me have the reſt. (Frank puts the other books and all the papers in his ſiſter's lap, who ſays, when ſhe receives them,) Well, every body muſt acknowledge that girls are cleverer than boys.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O yes, and you particularly. Iſabella is conſtantly employed in putting by your ſhreds and rags.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And if your tutor had not conſtantly his eye upon you, you would never know where you ſhould find your exerciſes and tranſlations. (She looks about her.) But I fancy I have now got them all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, yes; there is nothing left; ſo get you gone. (Lucy goes out.)

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p:
(putting back the chairs and tables in their places.) There; ſo that is done, and we
ſhall now have elbow-room enough. I cannot help thinking what fine work we ſhall be ſure to make. However, I am ſurpriſed that they are not come yet. For my part, I can ſay I hardly ever make any one wait for me when a viſit is in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.stage: (entering once again, and looking round about.)
sp.p: Ay, very well: but, brother, you muſt hide this ſpeaking trumpet. If your friends ſhould happen to perceive it, they will be ſure to ſtun us with their noiſe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay; I will put it up behind the door, as perhaps I ſhall want it. Let your little friends come now and din me with their chattering, as they uſed to do, and we ſhall ſee who will cry out loudeſt.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Pſha! we need but join together; we ſhould very ſhortly get the upper hand of ſuch a little thing as you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O no; for if you ladies have your clappers ſo well hung, we gentlemen poſſeſs a fine clear manly voice, which every one reſpects: as thus—You hear me?

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Yes; and have ſo much reſpect, as you ſay, for you, that I will take myſelf away. Farewel. I will run and join my friends.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And bid the ſervant ſend me up my viſitors when they arrive.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, yes. (She withdraws.)

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p:
Here is what has often brought me from the furtheſt corner of the garden, much againſt my inclination; and, I think, I hear it ſtill. —So ho! there! Frank! Frank!—My young friends live only at the corner of the ſtreet. Let me ſee if I can hurry them. (He puts the trumpet to his mouth, throws up the window, and cries out,)
Girls and boys come out to play,
The moon doth ſhine as bright as day:
Come with a whoop, and come with a call,
Come with good-will or not at all.
(He leaves the window, and draws near the door.) Well, is not this ſurpriſing! It is like Harlequin's enchanted horn. I think I hear them talking to each other on the ſtairs. (He liſtens.) Yes, yes! I proteſt the two Danby's (He puts the trumpet by.) Suppoſe I were to jump on the table, and receive them ſitting on my throne? (He runs to fetch a ſtool that he may put it one the table; and prepares to take a ſpring, but the arrival of the two Danby's prevents him.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Could not you have ſtaid a little at the door till I was mounted on my throne, that I might give you audience, as they ſay, in all my glory?

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Good, indeed! you have no occaſion to look exactly like a king. And active as you are, the throne might poſſibly cauſe your majeſty a tumble.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, to ſay the truth, I have read of many tumbles of that nature in my ancient hiſtory.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: And in ſome ſort, ſuch an accident has happened to my brother, though he is no great prince. He fell down ſtairs laſt week, and hurt his noſe conſiderably.

sp.speaker: Younger Danby,
sp.p: Yes, indeedeed! It pains me ſti-ſtill a little, and that ma-a-aſter Roberts is a very nau-au-aughty boy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Does he deſign to come to-night?

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: I hope not: if we had expected him here, we ſhould not have ſtirred out.

sp.speaker: Younger Danby.
sp.p: He o-o-only thinks of mis-miſchief.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What has he done then?

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: We were both going out laſt Saturday. I ſtopped to get a handkerchief: my brother went down ſtairs alone, and, as it happened, Roberts hearing ſome one, came out ſlily, jumped at once upon my brother, who was frighted, loſt his footing, and rolled down the ſtairs from top to bottom.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Poor Danby! I am ſorry for you.
Roberts looks for all the world as if he loved ſuch miſchief. We ſhall have his company this evening for the firſt time in our lives, his father begged papa to let him come and ſee us.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it; for we do not ſpeak to one another.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My papa ſuppoſed you all good friends, becauſe you lodge together, and conſidered that you would have the greater pleaſure if he came.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: The greater pleaſure! We ſhould like to have him ten miles off. Since he has been our neighbour, we are continually uneaſy. He has frequently amuſed himſelf with breaking windows, and then tried to lay the blame on us.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Does no one complain about him to his father?

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Oh! I do not know what to make of him, he is ſuch an odd ſort of a man! He ſcolds a little, pays the damage, and that is all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If I were your papa, I would quit my lodgings, and live ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p:
Yes, ſo he means to do, and therefore yeſterday gave warning; and now we are forbidden all manner of connection with this Roberts, he is ſo wicked! Would you think it, very few go by the houſe, without
being apprehenſive that he will put ſome trick upon them. Sometimes he diverts himſelf by ſquirting puddle water at them, or elſe pelting them with rotten apples. Nay, he will ſometimes faſten rabbits tails or bits of rags behind their backs, at which the people, when they ſee it, all burſt out a laughing. Then too he has what he calls his caxen fiſhery.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Caxen fiſhery!

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Yes: he will take the people's wigs off, as they paſs him, with a hook, as you would carp. When any poor man ſtops before his window to converſe with an acquaintance, Roberts immediately goes up to the balcony, with a ſtring ſuſpended from a fiſhing-rod, and at the end of it a hook, with which he jerks the poor man's wig off. Then he runs and ties it to a dog that he has before provided for the purpoſe, after which he drives the creature out into the ſtreet, and off he ſets that inſtant, ſo that the poor perriwig has frequently been dragged for twenty minutes through the mud, before its owner can lay hold of it again.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But this is more than mere amuſement!

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p:
And yet this is nothing to the ſtories that I could tell you. Why, he lames or bruiſes all the dogs and cats that
come within his reach. Nor is it long ago, when one of his relations broke a leg, by ſlipping down upon the ſtairs where Roberts had been ſcattering peas on purpoſe. Ay, it is ſo; or elſe our name is not Danby. And for the ſervants, I am ſure, his father would not get one to attend him, if he did not pay extraordinary wages.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Shall I tell you now? I long to ſee him. I like boys a little merry.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Nothing is more natural: but Roberts's mirth is not like other children's. You, I know, love laughing in your heart; but would not, for the world, hurt any one; whereas this wicked fellow laughs at bumps and bruiſes.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh, that does not fright me in the leaſt. I ſhall be much more pleaſed in paying him as he deſerves.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: If he ſhould come, my brother will not offend you by withdrawing? He would do him ſome freſh miſchief.

sp.speaker: Younger Danby.
sp.p: Ye-ye-yes, I will go.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, no: we are old friends; and poſitively no new comer ſhall divide us. I will take care and manage him, I warrant you.—But do not I hear a noiſe upon the ſtairs?—It is Roberts.—No, I ſee my ſiſter and her company.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Frank, Elder Danby, Younger Danby, Lucy, Iſabella, Dorinda, Alice, Laura.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, my good friends! but why not ſeated, brother? You might eaſily have got the gentlemen a chair a-piece, ſince they have been with you. Sure there has been time enough.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As if we did not know that it is uſual to ſtand up when we receive ladies.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am charmed to find you know your duty; but where is maſter Roberts? (to the Danbys.) I did ſuppoſe that you would have brought him with you.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: It is a long time now, thank Heaven, ſince we have been ſeparated from him.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: Is he then unluckier than Lucy's brother?

sp.speaker: Laura,
sp.p: Certainly he would be unlucky then, indeed!

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Lucy's brother! He is a very lamb to Roberts. We have known him for a long time. Have we not, dear ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: We have, and he has played me many a trick.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: He was very intimate with Anthony, my brother; but he is rid of him entirely now: why, he is the ſaddeſt fellow in the world!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, as for that, my brother is even with him there.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: But to do miſchief merely for the pleaſure of it—there is the villainy!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, no, my brother is better than that comes to.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Do you really think ſo? I am obliged to you!

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: Well, well, my dear Lucy, we will be under your protection, you are the biggeſt of us; and beſides, at preſent you are miſtreſs of the houſe, and may command him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Do not you be afraid. I will keep him perfectly in bounds.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Lucy: you ſhall take care of the ladies, and for you, (to the Danbys') I will take you under my protection.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Oh! he will hardly think of playing tricks with me. He knows me, I aſſure you. I only fear for my brother.

sp.speaker: Younger Danby.
sp.p: He makes ga-ga-me of me! yes, al-al-ways!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: That is his way; he always attacks the leaſt. He would never vex my ſiſter,—none but me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
I can believe you: ſuch as he are always cowards. I compare him to a puppy following cloſe upon a cat as long as ſhe keeps running: but if once the cat turns
round, and ſhews her whiſkers, then the puppy ſcampers for it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well then, ſiſter, you ſhall be the cat.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And let him ſee your whiſkers.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But methinks it would not be amiſs if we ſat down. Though we expect this Mr. Miſchief-maker, we have no need, I fancy, to remain ſtanding up till he chuſes to appear.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Huſh! here he is.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Frank, Elder Danby, Young Danby, Lucy, Iſabella, Dorinda, Alice, Laura, Roberts.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.stage: (to Frank and his ſiſter, making them a bow.)
sp.p: Your ſervant. Your papa was pleaſed to let me wait upon you: ſo I am come to ſpend the evening with you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: We are glad to ſee you, and ſhall have a deal of pleaſure in your company, at leaſt my brother.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Yes, indeed; he wants for good example.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do I? So your g •• d example, you would have the gentleman • uppoſe, is not ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Well, a truce to compliments. As miſtreſs of the houſe, it is neceſſary that I
ſhould let you know who is who. This tall young lady, in the firſt place, is Miſs Dorinda Lambton.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: I am charmed to hear it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And theſe are the Miſs—

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: O, I know them very well. This here is (pointing to Alice) my lady—what is her name? Pentweazle, that will take you off the company, as ſimple as ſhe ſeems: and there is (pointing to Laura, and limping round the room) Miſs Up-and-down, who broke her leg by running from the rod. This gentleman, (Elder Danby) obſerve him, he is a grave wiſe Grecian, who looks ſtrait before him when he walks, as if he pitied us poor ſilly children. And this other good little friend of mine (pointing to younger Danby, and letting fall his hat) is Pe-pe-peter Grievous, whoſe dear mama forgot, poor creature! to untie his tongue when he was born. (The children ſeem ſurprized, and ſtare at one another.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And who am I, ſir, for methinks you ſeem quite clever at this ſort of portrait painting?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Oh, I am not ſufficiently acquainted with you yet, to take your likeneſs: but I ſhall let you have it ſoon.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
For you, ſir, I could draw you at a
glance, and I muſt tell you, the ſimilitude would not be very pleaſing. I could never have ſuppoſed it poſſible that any well bred little gentleman, as I imagine you affect to be, ſhould think of turning natural defects into a theme for banter. If my little friends were not ſincerely ſuch, they would have reaſon to reproach me for expoſing them to your indecency. But they can ſee that I could not have expected half ſo much myſelf.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Why, Frank, I proteſt your ſiſter is mighty eloquent. You need not go to church on Sundays, having ſuch a charming preacher in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: She has tolerable ſkill, when any one is to be told the truth; and therefore both my ſiſter Iſabella and I love her ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Well, well, you ſee I have tolerable ſkill likewiſe in telling truth; and therefore no doubt you will love me, too, ſincerely. (He bows to Lucy.) I aſk your pardon, miſs, for having taken the employment out of your hands, as you are yourſelf ſo clever at it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Your excuſes and your bow are both an inſult; but an inſult ſuch as I deſpiſe. Though, were they on the other hand ſincere, they would hardly make atonement for ſo coarſe an incivility. If I had not conſidered
every word that you ſaid as meant in joke, however groſs I cannot but ſuppoſe it, I ſhould know what ſuited me to do, and ſhould have done it likewiſe. Let me therefore beg, ſir, that you will indulge in no more freedoms of this nature, if you mean that we ſhould remain together.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Well, but I ſee, you do not underſtand a little harmleſs piece of banter. Let us be friends. (He holds out his hand.)

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: With all my heart, ſir; but provided—

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.stage: (turning his back ſuddenly upon Lucy, and addreſſing young Danby.)
sp.p: You are an honeſt little fellow, too, and I will ſhake hands with you. (He heſitates to give his hand, and therefore Roberts ſeizing on him, ſhakes his arm ſo roughly, that he falls a crying.)

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Maſter Roberts!

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Pray, ſir, let this child alone; or—

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Well—or what?—my little Jack-a-dandy.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I am little, I acknowledge, but yet ſtrong enough; and ſo you will find me, when my friends require to be defended.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p:
Say you ſo? in that caſe I ſhould like to be one of them. But beforehand, if you pleaſe, we will have a bruſh, juſt to ſee
how you will be able to defend them.— (Roberts on a ſudden tries to fling him down; but Frank ſtands his ground, and Roberts falls. The company ruſh in to part them.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But one moment, if you pleaſe, young ladies. I will not do him any harm. Well, Mr. Roberts, pray how do you find yourſelf? I fancy, I am your maſter.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Take your knee off, —or you will ſtifle me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, no; you muſt not think of getting up, unleſs you firſt aſk pardon.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Pardon!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and of all the company, as you have certainly offended all the company.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Well, well; I do aſk pardon.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If you ſhould inſult us again, be aſſured, we will ſend you down into the cellar till to-morrow morning, which will ſurely cool your courage. That is much better than to hurt you. We do not think you worth the trouble.—Riſe. (He gets from off him, and when both are up, continues,) You have no right to be offended; for remember, it was yourſelf began the conteſt. (Roberts ſeems aſhamed.)

sp.speaker: Dorinda,
sp.p: I could never have ſuppoſed your brother half ſo valiant!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p:
Oh! a lion is hardly bolder; and
yet, Dorinda, he never quarrels. He is, in ſhort, although I ſay it, the beſt tempered little fellow in the world. (To the company.) But what are we doing? We ought to think of ſome amuſement for the evening.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Certainly we ought, or why are we all come together? Well, what play ſhall we chuſe? Something funny? What ſay you, Danby?

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: We will let the ladies chuſe. (Roberts makes mouths at Frank and Danby: the reſt pretend as if they did not ſee him.)

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: There, Frank, there is a leſſon for you: we may chuſe. Well then, ſuppoſe we play at queſtions and commands? or poſſibly you would like a game at cards much better?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I ſhould rather play at ſomething with the leaſt Danby: if you have a picturebook, we will turn it over: ſhall we?

sp.speaker: Younger Danby.
sp.p: O-o-o-oh, yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: With all my heart, ſweet dears! I will carry you up ſtairs. You will neither want for pictures nor playthings there. (Laura and the younger Danby take hold of one another by the hand, and jump for joy.)

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: My friends, will you go with me for amuſement into my apartment? I have a charming bonnet that you will like to ſee.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes; let us go.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Will you accept my hand as far as your apartment, Miſs Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Rather let Miſs Dorinda or Alice have it, if they pleaſe.

div.stage: (The elder Danby preſents his hand to Alice, who happens to ſtand next him.)

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: What then, do you mean to leave me by myſelf here?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, ſir; theſe young ladies will excuſe me, ſo I ſhall ſtay; but I am obliged to leave you for a moment.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Are you? but I will follow you. I do not like to be left alone by night, and in a houſe where I am a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: The truth is, I was apprehenſive leſt you might think of playing me ſome trick, ſo I accompanied you. But now that we are returned, and all alone, we may deviſe ſome mirth between us.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Very willingly; I aſk no better: ſo let us think a little.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: We muſt have ſome fun, I fancy, with the younger Danby.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If by fun you mean ſome trick to hurt him, I ſay no: I will not be in a joking humour; ſo pray leave him out if you are bent on miſchief.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: They told me that you were always merry, and fond of ſomething funny.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And ſo I am: but, notwithſtanding, without hurt to any one. However, let me know what ſort of fun you meant.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Look you: here are two large needles. I will ſtick them both with the points upward in the bottom of two chairs, that common eyes ſhall not diſcern them. in the next place you ſhall offer two of theſe young ladies the two chairs, for very likely they would ſuſpect that I meant them miſchief of ſome ſort or other, and they will naturally both ſit down; but figure to yourſelf what ſtrange grimaces they will both make! Ha! ha! ha! ha! It makes me die a laughing, when I barely think what faces we ſhall ſee them put on! Ay, ay, and your prudiſh ſiſter, too, will find the matter quite diverting.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe I were to treat you juſt in the ſame manner, would you like it?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Oh! treat me! that is different; but thoſe little idiots—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So you call them idiots, do you, ſince they are not miſchievous?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Well, you are mighty formal and preciſe. Then ſhall I mention ſomething elſe?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, do.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Then I have ſome thread as ſtrong as whipcord in my pocket. I will thread one of theſe great needles with a little of it; and as ſoon as they are all come down, one of us ſhall go up very politely towards them, make a deal of ſcraping, and wry faces, while the other, keeping ſtill behind, ſhall ſew their gowns together. They will all want to dance, as you may gueſs; ſo up we will come, and take them out.—Ha! ha! you know the reſt; ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, to tear their gowns, and get them anger when their parents find it out?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Why there is the fun.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What! have you no pleaſure then in any thing but doing miſchief?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: But is does not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O ho! I underſtand: you think of no one but yourſelf, and all the world is nothing to you!

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Well; but we are come together to divert ourſelves, and we muſt poſitively have ſome laughing. So ſuppoſe we frighten Laura and the leaſt Danby?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But that is quite wrong. Suppoſing any one ſhould frighten you?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: With all my heart, if any one is but able. I am afraid of nothing.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Say you ſo?—That we ſhall ſee, perhaps.— (Aloud to Roberts.) Well, about this frightening?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: I have an ugly maſk at home. I will run and fetch it. And do you, when I am gone, contrive to bring the little children down, and you ſhall ſee—I will not be abſent half a minute.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Good!—There ſhall be a better maſk ready for you, though!— To Roberts, calling him back. But Roberts! Roberts!

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It will be better that we ſhould come upon them where we are, if I can bring the others down; for when there are but two or three in this part of the houſe, there ſometimes comes a ſpirit; and in that caſe, we ourſelves ſhould be but badly off.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: What is all this ſtory of a ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, it is true. At firſt one hears a noiſe, and then a phantom with a lighted torch glides by, and then the room ſeems all on fire. (He draws back, as if afraid.) Oh! methinks I ſee it now.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: See what?— O dear!—And what can bring the phantom here?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.stage: (drawing Roberts towards a corner, and then whiſpering to him.)
sp.p: The reaſon, as we are told, is this: There was a mi • er who lived here formerly, and he was robbed one night of all his money: in deſpair he cut his throat, and now from time to time his ghoſt goes up and down—

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: O ho! I will ſtay no longer here, unleſs you get more company.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But recollect how brave you were juſt now.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: You muſt not fancy I am afraid: —but—but—but—but—but I will go and fetch my maſk.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do, do; and I will prepare things here.—What pleaſure we ſhall have!

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Oh! enough to make one die with laughing!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: They will be finely frightened!

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: That they will! and therefore I will make haſte. I am at home and back again—you ſhall ſee how ſoon! (He goes out.)

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Ah! ah! you want to frighten others, and are not afraid yourſelf! Well, well, I have thought of ſomething that will frighten you, or I am very much miſtaken.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Frank, Lucy, Iſabella, Dorinda, Alice, Elder Danby.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: We ſaw Maſter Roberts run acroſs the ſtreet this moment—What is the matter? Have you had a quarrel?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: On the contrary, he thinks me his beſt friend. I have ſeemed willing to go ſhares with him in a trick that he means to put upon the little ones above; but it is himſelf that he will trick, and never wiſh to come here a third time.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, what is your project?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You ſhall know very ſoon. At preſent I have no time to loſe, for every thing muſt be in readineſs againſt his coming back: ſo, ladies, I requeſt permiſſion to be abſent for about five minutes.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: Yes, go, go: but do not ſtay longer. We are all impatient to be told what you deſign.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I ſhall conſider it my duty to inform you when I have finiſhed my preparations. So once more with your leave. I will come again in leſs, perhaps, than five minutes. (He goes out.)

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah!—Two pretty fellows together! We ſhall ſee what good comes out between them! They are well matched.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: Oh! for Heaven's ſake, Miſs Lucy, do not do ſuch diſhonour to my friend, your brother, as to name him and that wicked Roberts together.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: You are in the right, Danby. One is nothing but politeneſs, and the other quite a ſavage.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Savage as he is, however, I would lay a wager that Frank will be found his maſter.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: What a piece of ſervice Frank would do us, could he clear the houſe of ſuch a fellow! We ſhall have no pleaſure all the evening if he ſtays among us.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am afraid, however, Frank will proceed too far, and think himſelf permitted to do any thing againſt this Roberts.

sp.speaker: Elder Danby.
sp.p: He can never do enough; and though his ſcheme ſhould be a little hard on Roberts, there will be inſtruction in it: it is the greateſt ſervice that one can do him: and his father, I am perſuaded, will be pleaſed with Frank, when he hears what pains he has taken to inſtruct his ſon. Alas! he would part with half his fortune to have Roberts like him.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: So, Lucy, do not you go about to thwart your brother's good intentions.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
But, my dear Miſs Alice, I am in a tickliſh ſituation: I am now inſtead of my
mama, and cannot poſſibly let any thing go forward that ſhe would not approve.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Let him have his way. We will take the blame of what he does upon ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Yes, let him ſiſter. War, I ſay, war; war for ever with the wicked!

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I have ſettled every thing, and Roberts may appear whenever he thinks proper. We will receive him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But, I hope, you will tell me—

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: Yes, we will be in the plot too: and more than that, aſſiſt you if we can.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, ladies, that is not neceſſary. There is a little violence, I muſt acknowledge, in my plot, and therefore I will not make you parties. I have been ſettling every thing with Ralph in the ſtable. He conceives my meaning clearly, and will ſecond it with great dexterity.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But ſtill, you do not acquaint me—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This is all of the contrivance that you need know. We will go to Blind-man's Buff, that Roberts may ſuſpect no harm on his return. I will let myſelf be caught, and he or ſhe that blinds me muſt take care that I may have an opportunity of ſeeing through the handkerchief, and fixing upon Roberts. After he is blinded, you ſhall ſteal into the cloſet, take away the lights, and leave us both together. When I want your aid, I will call you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It is maſter Roberts; but he was not in the play. You muſt begin again.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Frank is right.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo; but if I catch you again, it ſhall be all fair. Remember, I have warned you.

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: O yes, yes. (He takes Frank aſide, and lets him ſee a little of the maſk.) What think you of it?

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: O how frightful! I ſhould certainly be terrified at ſeeing it myſelf. Well, hide it carefully: we will play a little, and then ſlip away.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Yes, yes, we will: but I muſt, firſt of all, do ſomething to teize the ladies.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I will go up to Dorinda, and turn her round: if ſhe ſhould catch me, ſhe will ſuppoſe it to be you, and muſt ſet out again.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Good! good! I will have a little ſun with her too.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Well; when will you have told each other all your ſecrets? Two fine gentlemen! why, do not you ſee, the game ſtands ſtill?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: You need not ſtay for us; we are ready.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.stage: (keeping near Miſs Dorinda, as if he wiſhed to pull her by the gown, and ſeeing Roberts go to fetch a chair,)
sp.p: Now, Miſs Dorinda, I will put myſelf into your way.

p.hi:
(Roberts brings a chair, and puts it ſo that Dorinda may tumble over it; but Frank takes it away, and puts himſelf inſtead, upon his hands and feet, with ſo much noiſe, that Dorinda may hear him. As ſhe ſlides
along her feet, as if at hazard, ſhe encounters Frank, ſloops and ſeizes him.)

sp.speaker: Dorinda,
sp.stage: (after having felt about his cape and wriſts, and ſeeming doubtful)
sp.p: It is Maſter Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Yes, indeed; I am taken. What ill luck! ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Dorinda,
sp.p: O, ho! you wanted to throw me down! I thought nobody but maſter Roberts played ſuch tricks; but it ſhall not be long before I take revenge. (She covers Frank's eyes, ſo that he can ſee a little, leads him towards the middle of the room, and, as is the cuſtom of the game, aſks him,) How many horſes in your father's ſtable?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Three; black, white, and grey.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: Turn about three times, and catch whom you may. (Frank gropes about, and lets himſelf be joſiled as they pleaſe. Dorinda particularly plagues him; he pretends to follow her, but all at once turns round, and falls on Roberts.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ah! ha! I have caught you! have I? It is a boy. It is Roberts! (pulling of the handkerchief.) Yes, yes; I am not miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Why lay hold on me?

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Do not mind it. You ſhall catch Danby. I will puſh him towards you.

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: Do, and you ſhall ſee how I will make him ſqueak: I will pinch him till the very blood comes. (Frank covers Roberts's eyes, and nods to the company as he had ſettled it. Elder Danby and the little ladies t • ke away the lights, and all together run into an adjoining cloſet quietly.)

sp.speaker: Elder Danby,
sp.p:
Well: have you finiſhed? Oh make haſte. You take a
deal of time. What miſchief are you whiſpering to each other? (Here the groom preſents himſelf at the door, with a lighted torch in one hand, and a ſtick beneath it in the other, with a large full-bottomed wig upon it. He is covered over with Mr. Jephſon's gown, trailing on the ground behind him. Frank beckous him to keep back, while he is blinding Roberts)

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.stage: (putting Roberts in the middle of the room.)
sp.p: How many horſes in your father's ſtable?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Three; black, white and grey.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Turn about— (pretending to be angry with the others.) Be quiet pray, young ladies, and not quit your places till the game is begun.—Turn about three times, and catch whom you may.— (While Roberts turns about, Frank runs for the ſpeaking trumpet, bids the groom untie a chain that he has about his waiſt, which falling makes a hideous noiſe, and then he cries out luſtily himſelf,) The ghoſt! the ghoſt! Run, Roberts, for your life. (He claps the door to violently, hides himſelf behind the Groom, and ſpeaking through the trumpet, ſays,) It is you then that come to ſteal my treaſure?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.stage: (trembling with fear, and not daring to pull off the bandage.)
sp.p: Fire! fire! Danby! Where are you, Frank! Murder! murder! Dorinda!

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I have ſeared them all away. Pull off your bandage, and look at me. (Roberts, without pulling off the bandage, puts his hands up to his face, retiring from the ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pull it off, I ſay— (Roberts pulls the bandage down about his neck, but dare not lift his eyes up, and at laſt, when he obſerves the ghoſt, he ſcreams out, and has not power to move.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
I know you well, your name is Roberts. (Roberts hearing this, runs up and down to get
away, but finding the door ſhut, falls down upon his knees, holds out his hands, and turns away his head.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What you think to eſcape me, do you?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: I have done nothing to you. You were never robbed by me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Never robbed by you? You are capable of any villainy! Who ſquirts at people in the ſtreet? Who faſtens rabbits' tails behind their backs? Who fiſhes for their wigs? Who lames poor dogs and cats? Who ſticks up pins in chairs to prick his friends when they ſit down! And who has in his pocket even now, a maſk to frighten two poor little children?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: I have done all this! indeed, I own it! but for heaven's ſake pardon me, and I will not do ſo any more.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Who will anſwer for you?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Thoſe that you have frightened away, if you will but call them.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do you promiſe me yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Yes, yes; upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well then, I take pity on you; but remember, had it been my pleaſure, I might eaſily fly away with you through the window. (Here the phantom makes his torch glare like lightning, and then goes out. Roberts, almoſt ſwooning with terror, ſalls on his face.)

div.head: SCENE the Laſt.
div.stage: Roberts, Frank, the Groom, Mr. Jephſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon,
sp.stage: (entering with a candle in his hand.)
sp.p: What is all this diſturbance?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: It is not I that make it. Pray, pray, do not come near me!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon,
sp.p: Who can this be on the ground?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: You know me well enough, and have already taken pity on me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: I already taken pity on you!

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: It was not I that robbed you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: Robbed me! what does all this mean? do not I know you, maſter Roberts?—

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Yes, yes; that is my name, good ghoſt: ſo pray do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed! why in ſuch a poſture? (He puts down the light, and lifts him up.)

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.stage: (ſtruggling firſt of all, but knowing Mr. Jephſon after wards.)
sp.p: Mr. Jephſon, is it you? (his features brighten) He is gone then! is he? (he looks round about him, ſees the ghoſt, and turns away again.) There, there he ſtands!—the phantom! —don't you ſee him? (Frank brings the children from the cloſet. Laura and younger Danby are frightened at the groom's appearance, but the reſt burſt out a laughing.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: Well! what ſignifies all this?

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Let me explain the whole, papa. This phantom is your groom; and we have put on him your wig and gown.

sp.speaker: Groom,
sp.p: Yes, ſir, it is I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeph.
sp.p: An odd ſort of ſport this, Frank!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: True, but aſk the company if maſter Roberts has not well deſerved to be thus frightened. He deſigned to frighten Laura and Danby: I only wiſhed to hinder him. Let him but ſhew the frightful maſk that he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon,
sp.p: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: I cannot deny it: here it is, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: You have met with nothing, then, but what you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: We perſuaded Miſs Lucy to permit her brother to make uſe of this device to puniſh Roberts.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: If you knew beſides, ſir, all the other tricks that he meant to play us—

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: What, ſir, is this the ſample that you give us of your behaviour, the firſt time you ſet foot within my doors? You have been diſreſpectful to me in the perſon of my children, who were pleaſed with the expectation of having you as their gueſt. You have been diſreſpectful to theſe ladies, whom I need not ſay you ſhould have honoured and regarded. So be gone! Your father, when he comes to know that you have been turned out of doors, will ſee how neceſſary it is to correct the vices of your heart. I will not permit your deteſtable example to corrupt my children. Go, and never let me ſee you here again! (Roberts is confounded, and withdraws.) And you, my friends, although the circumſtances of the caſe may very poſſibly excuſe what you have done, yet never, for the time to come, indulge yourſelves in ſuch ſport. The fears which have power to affect children at a tender age, may poſſibly be followed by the worſt conſequences during their whole life. Avenge yourſelves upon the wicked only by behaving better; and remember, after the example which maſter Roberts has afforded you, that by intending harm to others, you will ofteneſt bring it down upon yourſelves.
